<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Yogurt skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Yogurt</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_prepared_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox prepared food (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox prepared food</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cacik-1.jpg" title="File:Cacik-1.jpg">File:Cacik-1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cac%C4%B1k&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cacık (page does not exist)">Cacık</a></i>, a Turkish cold appetizer yogurt variety</div></div></div>
<p><b>Yogurt</b> or <b>yoghurt</b> or <b>yoghourt</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-tr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-tr (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-tr</a>; other spellings listed <a href="#spellings">below</a>) is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermented_milk_product&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermented milk product (page does not exist)">fermented milk product</a> (<a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant milk (page does not exist)">nut milks</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Almond_milk" title="Almond milk">almond milk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Coconut_milk" title="Coconut milk">coconut milk</a> can also be used) produced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacterial</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (food) (page does not exist)">fermentation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Milk" title="Milk">milk</a>. The bacteria used to make yogurt are known as "yogurt cultures". Fermentation of <a href="/wiki/Lactose" title="Lactose">lactose</a> by these bacteria produces <a href="/wiki/Lactic_acid" title="Lactic acid">lactic acid</a>, which acts on milk <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">protein</a> to give yogurt its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Texture_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Texture (food) (page does not exist)">texture</a> and its characteristic tang.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> 
</p><p>Worldwide, <a href="/wiki/Cow%27s_milk" title="Cow's milk" class="mw-redirect">cow's milk</a>, the protein of which mainly comprises <a href="/wiki/Casein" title="Casein">casein</a>, is most commonly used to make yogurt, but milk from <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo">water buffalo</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Goat (page does not exist)">goats</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sheep&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sheep (page does not exist)">ewes</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mare&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mare (page does not exist)">mares</a>, <a href="/wiki/Camel" title="Camel">camels</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yak" title="Yak">yaks</a> is also used in various parts of the world.
</p><p>Dairy yogurt is produced using a culture of <a href="/wiki/Lactobacillus_delbrueckii_subsp._bulgaricus" title="Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp. bulgaricus"><i>Lactobacillus delbrueckii</i> subsp. <i>bulgaricus</i></a> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Streptococcus_thermophilus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Streptococcus thermophilus (page does not exist)">Streptococcus thermophilus</a></i> bacteria. In addition, other <a href="/wiki/Lactobacillus" title="Lactobacillus">lactobacilli</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bifidobacterium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bifidobacterium (page does not exist)">bifidobacteria</a> are also sometimes added during or after culturing yogurt. Some countries require yogurt to contain a certain amount of colony-forming units of microorganisms.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Western culture, the milk is first heated to about 80 °C (176 °F) to kill any undesirable bacteria and to <a href="/wiki/Denaturation_(biochemistry)" title="Denaturation (biochemistry)">denature</a> the milk proteins so that they set together rather than form curds. In some places, such as parts of India, curds are a desired component and milk is not pasteurized but boiled. The milk is then cooled to about 45 °C (112 °F).<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fact&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fact (page does not exist)">Template:Fact</a> The bacterial culture is added, and the temperature is maintained for 4 to 7 hours to allow fermentation.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>

<ul>

</ul>
</li>

<ul>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_spelling">Etymology and spelling</span></h2>
<p>The word is derived from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-tr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-tr (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-tr</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> and is related to the verb <i>yoğurmak</i>: "to be curdled or coagulated; to thicken".<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> The letter <a href="/wiki/%C4%9E" title="Ğ">ğ</a> was traditionally rendered as "gh" in transliterations of Turkish prior to 1928.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> In older Turkish, the letter denoted a <a href="/wiki/Voiced_velar_fricative" title="Voiced velar fricative">voiced velar fricative</a> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ɣ/</span>, but this sound is <a href="/wiki/Elision" title="Elision">elided</a> between <a href="/wiki/Back_vowel" title="Back vowel">back vowels</a> in modern Turkish, in which the word is pronounced <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-tr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-tr (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-tr</a>, or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-tr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-tr (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-tr</a>.
</p><p><span class="spellingvariants" id="spellings">In English, there are <a href="/wiki/American_and_British_English_spelling_differences" title="American and British English spelling differences">several variations of the spelling of the word</a>, including <i>yogurt</i>, <i>yoghurt</i>, <i>yoghourt</i>, <i>yogourt</i>, <i>yaghourt</i>, <i>yahourth</i>, <i>yoghurd</i>, <i>joghourt</i>, and <i>jogourt</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> In the United Kingdom and Australia, <i>yogurt</i> and <i>yoghurt</i> are both current, <i>yogurt</i> being more common<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated587_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated587-9">[9]</a></sup> and used by the Australian and British dairy councils,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> and <i>yoghourt</i> is an uncommon alternative.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated587_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated587-9">[9]</a></sup> In the United States, <i>yogurt</i> is the usual spelling and <i>yoghurt</i> a minor variant.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated587_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated587-9">[9]</a></sup> In <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a>, <i>yoghurt</i> is preferred by the <i>New Zealand Oxford Dictionary</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-NZOED_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NZOED-12">[12]</a></sup> In Canada, <i>yogurt</i> is most common among English speakers,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated587_9-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated587-9">[9]</a></sup> but many brands use <i>yogourt</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> since it is an acceptable spelling in both English and French, the official <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Canada" title="Languages of Canada">languages of Canada</a>.
</p><p>Historically there have also been cases of yogurt being spelt with a "J" instead of a "Y" due to alternative transliteration methodologies, such as Jogurt and Joghurt. However, there has been a decline in these variations, with most people tending to spell in the manner shown on the packaging of the major brands in their country.
</p><p>Whatever the spelling, the word is usually pronounced with a short <i>o</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> in England, with a long <i>o</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> in Scotland, North America, Australia, Ireland and South Africa, and with either a long or short <i>o</i> in New Zealand.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p>The origins of yogurt are unknown.  Analysis of the <i>L. delbrueckii</i> subsp. <i>bulgaricus</i> genome indicates that the bacterium may have originated on the surface of a plant.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Milk may have become spontaneously and unintentionally infected through contact with plants, or bacteria may have been transferred via the udder of domestic milk-producing animals.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>In ancient Indian records, the combination of yogurt and honey is called "the food of the gods".<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> Persian traditions hold that "<a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a> owed his <a href="/wiki/Fecundity" title="Fecundity">fecundity</a> and longevity to the regular ingestion of yogurt".<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>The oldest writings mentioning yogurt are attributed to <a href="/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder" title="Pliny the Elder">Pliny the Elder</a>, who remarked that certain "barbarous nations" knew how "to thicken the milk into a substance with an agreeable acidity".<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> The use of yogurt by medieval <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turks</a> is recorded in the books <i>Diwan Lughat al-Turk</i> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahmud_Kashgari&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahmud Kashgari (page does not exist)">Mahmud Kashgari</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Kutadgu_Bilig" title="Kutadgu Bilig">Kutadgu Bilig</a></i> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yusuf_Has_Hajib&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yusuf Has Hajib (page does not exist)">Yusuf Has Hajib</a> written in the 11th century.<sup id="cite_ref-toygar_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-toygar-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ogel_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ogel-20">[20]</a></sup> Both texts mention the word "yogurt" in different sections and describe its use by nomadic Turks.<sup id="cite_ref-toygar_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-toygar-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ogel_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ogel-20">[20]</a></sup> The earliest yogurts were probably spontaneously <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (food) (page does not exist)">fermented</a> by wild <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacteria</a> in goat skin bags.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some accounts suggest that Indian emperor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akbar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akbar (page does not exist)">Akbar's</a> cooks would use mustard seeds and cinnamon in yogurt to add flavor. <sup id="cite_ref-books.google_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-22">[22]</a></sup> Another early account of a European encounter with yogurt occurs in French clinical history: <a href="/wiki/Francis_I_of_France" title="Francis I of France">Francis I</a> suffered from a severe <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrhea</a> which no French doctor could cure. His ally <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a> sent a doctor, who allegedly cured the patient with yogurt.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-books.google_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-22">[22]</a></sup> Being grateful, the French king spread around the information about the food which had cured him.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Raita_with_cucumber_and_mint.jpg" title="File:Raita with cucumber and mint.jpg">File:Raita with cucumber and mint.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Raita" title="Raita">Raita</a> is a condiment made with yogurt and popular in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Until the 1900s, yogurt was a staple in diets of people in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian Empire (page does not exist)">Russian Empire</a> (and especially <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>), <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Eastern_Europe" title="South Eastern Europe" class="mw-redirect">South Eastern Europe</a>/<a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>, and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stamen_Grigorov&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stamen Grigorov (page does not exist)">Stamen Grigorov</a> (1878–1945), a <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgarian</a> student of medicine in <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a>, first examined the microflora of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bulgarian_yogurt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bulgarian yogurt (page does not exist)">Bulgarian yogurt</a>. In 1905, he described it as consisting of a spherical and a rod-like lactic acid bacteria. In 1907, the rod-like bacterium was called <i>Bacillus bulgaricus</i> (now <i><a href="/wiki/Lactobacillus_delbrueckii_subsp._bulgaricus" title="Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp. bulgaricus">Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp. bulgaricus</a></i>). The <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russian</a> <a href="/wiki/Nobel_laureate" title="Nobel laureate" class="mw-redirect">Nobel laureate</a> and  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biologist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biologist (page does not exist)">biologist</a> Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov (also seen as Élie Metchnikoff), from the <a href="/wiki/Institut_Pasteur" title="Institut Pasteur" class="mw-redirect">Institut Pasteur</a> in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>, was influenced by Grigorov's work and hypothesized that regular consumption of yogurt was responsible for the unusually long lifespans of <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians" title="Bulgarians">Bulgarian</a> peasants. Believing <i><a href="/wiki/Lactobacillus" title="Lactobacillus">Lactobacillus</a></i> to be essential for good health, Mechnikov worked to popularize yogurt as a foodstuff throughout Europe.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Isaac_Carasso&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isaac Carasso (page does not exist)">Isaac Carasso</a> industrialized the production of yogurt. In 1919, Carasso, who was from <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> <a href="/wiki/Salonika" title="Salonika" class="mw-redirect">Salonika</a>, started a small yogurt business in <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, and named the business <a href="/wiki/Groupe_Danone" title="Groupe Danone">Danone</a> ("little Daniel") after his son. The brand later expanded to the United States under an Americanized version of the name: <a href="/wiki/Dannon" title="Dannon" class="mw-redirect">Dannon</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TaratorBg.jpg" title="File:TaratorBg.jpg">File:TaratorBg.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Tarator" title="Tarator">Tarator</a> is a cold soup made of yogurt, cucumber, dill, garlic and sunflower oil (walnuts are sometimes added) and is popular in <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Yogurt with added fruit <a href="/wiki/Jam" title="Jam" class="mw-redirect">jam</a> was patented in 1933 by the Radlická Mlékárna dairy in <a href="/wiki/Prague" title="Prague">Prague</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yogurt was first introduced to the United States in the first decade of the twentieth century, influenced by <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lie_Metchnikoff" title="Élie Metchnikoff">Élie Metchnikoff</a>'s <i>The Prolongation of Life; Optimistic Studies</i> (1908); it was available in tablet form for those with digestive intolerance and for home culturing.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> It was popularized by <a href="/wiki/John_Harvey_Kellogg" title="John Harvey Kellogg">John Harvey Kellogg</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_Creek_Sanitarium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle Creek Sanitarium (page does not exist)">Battle Creek Sanitarium</a>, where it was used both orally and in <a href="/wiki/Enemas" title="Enemas" class="mw-redirect">enemas</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> and later by <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenian</a> immigrants Sarkis and Rose Colombosian, who started "Colombo and Sons Creamery" in <a href="/wiki/Andover,_Massachusetts" title="Andover, Massachusetts">Andover, Massachusetts</a> in 1929.<sup id="cite_ref-urlThe_Massachusetts_Historical_Society_.7C_Object_of_the_Month_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-urlThe_Massachusetts_Historical_Society_.7C_Object_of_the_Month-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-urlColombo_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-urlColombo-28">[28]</a></sup> Colombo Yogurt was originally delivered around New England in a horse-drawn wagon inscribed with the Armenian word "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Matsoni&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matsoni (page does not exist)">madzoon</a>" which was later changed to "yogurt", the Turkish name of the product, as Turkish was the <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> between immigrants of the various <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near Eastern</a> ethnicities who were the main consumers at that time. Yogurt's popularity in the United States was enhanced in the 1950s and 1960s, when it was presented as a <a href="/wiki/Health_food" title="Health food">health food</a>. By the late 20th century, yogurt had become a common American food item and Colombo Yogurt was sold in 1993 to <a href="/wiki/General_Mills" title="General Mills">General Mills</a>, which discontinued the brand in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutritional_value_and_health_benefits">Nutritional value and health benefits</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tzatziki_IMGP1430.jpg" title="File:Tzatziki IMGP1430.jpg">File:Tzatziki IMGP1430.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Tzatziki" title="Tzatziki" class="mw-redirect">Tzatziki</a> is a side dish made with yogurt, popular in Greek cuisine, and similar yet thicker than the Turkish <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cacik&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cacik (page does not exist)">Cacik</a> and close to the traditional Bulgarian <a href="/wiki/Milk_salad" title="Milk salad">Milk salad</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Yogurt is nutritionally rich in <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">protein</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riboflavin" title="Riboflavin">riboflavin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_B6" title="Vitamin B6">vitamin B6</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B12&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B12 (page does not exist)">vitamin B12</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-yale_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yale-30">[30]</a></sup> It has nutritional benefits beyond those of milk. <a href="/wiki/Lactose_intolerance" title="Lactose intolerance">Lactose-intolerant</a> individuals can sometimes tolerate yogurt better than other dairy products, because the lactose in the milk is converted to <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Galactose" title="Galactose">galactose</a>, and partially fermented to lactic acid, by the bacterial culture.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yogurt containing live cultures has been found effective in a randomized trial at preventing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antibiotic-associated_diarrhea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antibiotic-associated diarrhea (page does not exist)">antibiotic-associated diarrhea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
Yogurt contains varying amounts of <a href="/wiki/Fat" title="Fat">fat</a>. There is non-fat (0% fat), low-fat (usually 2% fat) and plain or whole milk yogurt (4% fat).<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> A study published in the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Journal_of_Obesity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Journal of Obesity (page does not exist)">International Journal of Obesity</a></i> (11 January 2005) also found that the consumption of low-fat yogurt can promote weight loss, relative to a gelatin placebo.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yogurt is a valuable health food for both infants and elderly persons. For children, it is a balanced source of protein, fats, carbohydrates, and minerals. For senior citizens, who usually have more sensitive colons or whose intestines have run out of lactase, yogurt is also a valuable food. Elderly intestines showed declining levels of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bifidobacterium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bifidobacterium (page does not exist)">bifidus bacteria</a>, which allow the growth of toxin-producing and, perhaps, cancer-causing bacteria. Yogurt may help prevent osteoporosis, reduce the risk of high blood pressure. Yogurt with active cultures helps the gut, may discourage vaginal infections, and may help one feel fuller.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>The "yogurt defense" was made famous by the trial of Carol Downer, one of the developers of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Menstrual_extraction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Menstrual extraction (page does not exist)">menstrual extraction</a>. She was arrested at her self-help group and charged with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Practicing_medicine_without_a_license&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Practicing medicine without a license (page does not exist)">practicing medicine without a license</a>, as she inserted yogurt into the vagina of another woman to treat a yeast condition.  Carol Downer was acquitted; the jury did not equate inserting yogurt with practicing medicine.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Varieties_and_presentation">Varieties and presentation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dadiah1.jpg" title="File:Dadiah1.jpg">File:Dadiah1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Dadiah sold in <a href="/wiki/Bukittinggi" title="Bukittinggi">Bukittinggi</a> Market</div></div></div>
<p><i>Da-hi</i> is a yogurt of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian subcontinent</a>, known for its characteristic taste and consistency. The word <i>da-hi</i> seems to be derived from the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> word <i>dadhi</i>, one of the five elixirs, or <a href="/wiki/Panchamrita" title="Panchamrita">panchamrita</a>, often used in Hindu ritual. <i>Dahi</i> also holds cultural symbolism in many homes in the <i>Mithila</i> region of <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a><sup>&lt;reference?&gt;</sup>. Yogurt balances the palate across regional cuisines throughout India. In the hot and humid south, yogurt and foods made of yogurt are a staple in order to cool down - yogurt rice is always the last dish of the meal. Also, the primarily vegetarian population of India derives some protein from yogurt (other than lentil and beans). Sweet yogurt (<i>meesti doi</i> or <i>meethi dahi</i>) is common in eastern parts of India, made by fermenting sweetened milk. While cow milk is considered sacred and is currently the primary ingredient for yogurt, in yesteryears goat milk and buffalo milk were widely used and valued for the fat content. Butter and cream were made by churning the yogurt/milk.
</p><p>In India and Pakistan, it is often used in cosmetics mixed with <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">turmeric</a> and honey. Sour yogurt, is also used as a <a href="/wiki/Hair_conditioner" title="Hair conditioner">hair conditioner</a> by women in many parts of India and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
<i>Dahi</i> is also known as <i>Mosaru</i> (<a href="/wiki/Kannada_language" title="Kannada language">Kannada</a>), <i>Thayir</i> (<a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a>), <i>Thayiru</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Malayalam_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malayalam language (page does not exist)">Malayalam</a>), <i>doi</i> (<a href="/wiki/Assamese_language" title="Assamese language">Assamese</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bengali_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bengali language (page does not exist)">Bengali</a>), <i>dohi</i> (<a href="/wiki/Oriya_language" title="Oriya language">Oriya</a>), <i>perugu</i> (<a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a>), <i>Qәzana a pәәner</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pashto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pashto (page does not exist)">Pashto</a>) and <i>Dhahi</i> or <i>Dhaunro</i> (<a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">Sindhi</a> <b>ڏهي، ڌونرو</b>)
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dadiah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dadiah (page does not exist)">Dadiah</a> or Dadih is a traditional West <a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatran</a> yogurt made from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Domestic_buffalo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Domestic buffalo (page does not exist)">water buffalo</a> milk, fermented in <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a> tubes.<sup id="cite_ref-Surono_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Surono-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yogurt is popular in <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, where it is served as both an appetizer and dessert. Locally called <i>dahi</i> (दही), it is a part of the Nepali culture, used in local festivals, marriage ceremonies, parties, religious occasions, family gatherings, and so on. The most famous type of Nepalese yogurt is called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dhau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dhau (page does not exist)">juju dhau</a></i>, originating from the city of <a href="/wiki/Bhaktapur" title="Bhaktapur">Bhaktapur</a>.
In <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a>, yak milk (technically dri milk, as the word yak refers to the male animal) is made into yogurt (and butter and cheese) and consumed.
</p><p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Iran&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Iran (page does not exist)">Northern Iran</a>, <i>Mâst Chekide</i> is a variety of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kefir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kefir (page does not exist)">kefir</a> yogurt with a distinct sour taste. It is usually mixed with a <a href="/wiki/Pesto" title="Pesto">pesto-like</a> water and fresh herb purée called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Delal_sauce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Delal sauce (page does not exist)">delal</a>. Yogurt is a side dish to all <a href="/wiki/Iranian_cuisine" title="Iranian cuisine">Iranian meals</a>. The most popular appetizers are <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a> or <a href="/wiki/Eggplant" title="Eggplant">eggplant</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Borani&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Borani (page does not exist)">borani</a>, <i>Mâst-o-Khiâr</i> with cucumber, spring onions and herbs, and <i>Mâst-Musir</i> with wild <a href="/wiki/Shallot" title="Shallot">shallots</a>. In the summertime, yogurt and ice cubes are mixed together with cucumbers, <a href="/wiki/Raisin" title="Raisin">raisins</a>, salt, pepper and <a href="/wiki/Onion" title="Onion">onions</a> and topped with some croutons made of Persian traditional bread and served as a cold soup. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ashe-M%C3%A2st&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ashe-Mâst (page does not exist)">Ashe-Mâst</a> is a warm yogurt soup with fresh herbs, spinach and lentils. Even the leftover water extracted when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Strained_yogurt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Strained yogurt (page does not exist)">straining yogurt</a> is cooked to make a sour cream sauce called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kashk (page does not exist)">kashk</a>, which is usually used as a topping on soups and stews.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Matsoni&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matsoni (page does not exist)">Matsoni</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgian</a> yogurt popular in the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>. It is used in a wide variety of Georgian dishes and is believed to have contributed to the high life expectancy and longevity in the country. <a href="/wiki/Dannon" title="Dannon" class="mw-redirect">Dannon</a> used this theory in their 1978 TV advertisement called <i>In Soviet Georgia</i> where shots of elderly <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgian</a> <a href="/wiki/Farmer" title="Farmer">farmers</a> were interspersed with an off-camera <a href="/wiki/Announcer" title="Announcer">announcer</a> intoning, "In Soviet Georgia, where they eat a lot of yogurt, a lot of people live past <a href="/wiki/Centenarian" title="Centenarian">100</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matsoni&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matsoni (page does not exist)">Matsoni</a> is also popular in <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> under the name <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ja:%E3%82%AB%E3%82%B9%E3%83%94%E6%B5%B7%E3%83%A8%E3%83%BC%E3%82%B0%E3%83%AB%E3%83%88&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ja:カスピ海ヨーグルト (page does not exist)">Caspian Sea Yogurt</a> (カスピ海ヨーグルト).
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Tarator" title="Tarator">Tarator</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cac%C4%B1k&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cacık (page does not exist)">Cacık</a> are popular cold soups made from yogurt, popular during summertime in <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> (known as Dogramac), <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_Macedonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of Macedonia (page does not exist)">Republic of Macedonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a>. They are made with <a href="/wiki/Ayran" title="Ayran">ayran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cucumber" title="Cucumber">cucumbers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dill" title="Dill">dill</a>, salt, <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">olive</a> oil, and optionally <a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">garlic</a> and ground <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walnut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walnut (page does not exist)">walnuts</a>. <a href="/wiki/Tzatziki" title="Tzatziki" class="mw-redirect">Tzatziki</a><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Milk_salad" title="Milk salad">milk salad</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> are thick yogurt-based salads similar to tarator.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Khyar_w_Laban&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Khyar w Laban (page does not exist)">Khyar w Laban</a> (cucumber and yogurt salad) is a popular dish in Lebanon and Syria. Also, a wide variety of local Lebanese and Syrian dishes are cooked with yogurt like "Kibbi bi Laban", etc.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rahmjoghurt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rahmjoghurt (page does not exist)">Rahmjoghurt</a>, a creamy yogurt with much higher fat content (10%) than many yogurts offered in English-speaking countries (<i>Rahm</i> is German for "cream"), is available in <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> and other countries.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dovga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dovga (page does not exist)">Dovga</a>, a yogurt soup cooked with a variety of herbs and rice is popular in Azerbaijan, often served warm in winter or refreshingly cold in summer. 
</p><p>Cream-top yogurt is yogurt made with unhomogenized milk. A layer of cream rises to the top, forming a rich yogurt cream. Cream-top yogurt was first made commercially popular in the United States by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brown_Cow_(yogurt)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brown Cow (yogurt) (page does not exist)">Brown Cow</a> of Newfield, New York, bucking the trend toward low- and non-fat yogurts.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Jameed" title="Jameed">Jameed</a> is yogurt which is salted and dried to preserve it. It is popular in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jordan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jordan (page does not exist)">Jordan</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Zabadi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zabadi (page does not exist)">Zabadi</a> is the type of yogurt made in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egypt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egypt (page does not exist)">Egypt</a>, usually from the milk of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Water_Buffalo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Water Buffalo (page does not exist)">Egyptian water buffalo</a>. It is particularly associated with <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a> fasting, as it is thought to prevent thirst during all-day fasting.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Raita" title="Raita">Raita</a> is a yogurt-based <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Asian_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Asian cuisine (page does not exist)">South Asian</a>/<a href="/wiki/Indian_food" title="Indian food" class="mw-redirect">Indian</a> <a href="/wiki/Condiment" title="Condiment">condiment</a>, used as a side dish. The yogurt is seasoned with <a href="/wiki/Coriander" title="Coriander">cilantro</a> (coriander), <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">mint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cayenne_pepper" title="Cayenne pepper">cayenne pepper</a>, and other herbs and spices. Vegetables such as <a href="/wiki/Cucumber" title="Cucumber">cucumber</a> and <a href="/wiki/Onion" title="Onion">onions</a> are mixed in, and the mixture is served chilled. Raita has a cooling effect on the palate which makes it a good foil for spicy Indian and Pakistani dishes. Raita is sometimes referred to as <i>dahi</i>.
</p><p><i>Dahi</i> is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sindhis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sindhis (page does not exist)">Sindhi</a>-curd, popular in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>. People drink <i>dahi</i> along with food at intervals, to help digestion and make food more delicious. In some places, <i>dahi</i> is also served with plain rice.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sweetened_and_flavored_yogurt">Sweetened and flavored yogurt</span></h3>
<p>To offset its natural <a href="/wiki/Sour" title="Sour" class="mw-redirect">sourness</a>, yogurt is also sold sweetened, flavored or in containers with <a href="/wiki/Fruit" title="Fruit">fruit</a> or fruit jam on the bottom.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The two styles of yogurt commonly found in the grocery store are set type yogurt and Swiss style yogurt. Set type yogurt is when the yogurt is packaged with the fruit on the bottom of the cup and the yogurt on top. Swiss style yogurt is when the fruit is blended into the yogurt prior to packaging.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lassi and Moru are common beverages in India. Lassi is milk that is sweetened with sugar commonly, less commonly honey and often combined with fruit pulp to create flavored lassi. Mango lassi is a western favorite, as is coconut lassi. Consistency can vary widely, with urban and commercial lassis being of uniform texture through being processed, whereas rural and rustic lassi has curds in it, and sometimes has malai (cream) added or removed. Moru is a popular South Indian summer drink, meant to keep drinkers hydrated through the hot and humid summers of the South. It is prepared by considerably thinning down yogurt with water, adding salt (for electrolyte balance) and spices, usually green chilli peppers, asafoetida, curry leaves and mustard. 
</p><p>Large amounts of <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> – or other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweetener&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweetener (page does not exist)">sweeteners</a> for low-calorie yogurts – are often used in commercial yogurt. Some yogurts contain added <a href="/wiki/Starch" title="Starch">starch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pectin" title="Pectin">pectin</a> (found naturally in fruit), and/or <a href="/wiki/Gelatin" title="Gelatin">gelatin</a> to create thickness and creaminess artificially at lower cost. This type of yogurt is also marketed under the name Swiss-style, although it is unrelated to the way yogurt is eaten in Switzerland. Some yogurts, often called "cream line," are made with whole milk which has not been homogenized so the cream rises to the top. Fruit <a href="/wiki/Jam" title="Jam" class="mw-redirect">jam</a> is used instead of raw fruit pieces in fruit yogurts to allow storage for weeks.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">UK</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">France</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_America" title="United States of America" class="mw-redirect">USA</a>, sweetened, flavored yogurt is the most popular type, typically sold in single-serving plastic cups. Common flavors include <a href="/wiki/Vanilla" title="Vanilla">vanilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honey" title="Honey">honey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Toffee" title="Toffee">toffee</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fruit" title="Fruit">fruit</a> such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Strawberry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Strawberry (page does not exist)">strawberry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cherry" title="Cherry">cherry</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blueberry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blueberry (page does not exist)">blueberry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blackberry" title="Blackberry">blackberry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raspberry" title="Raspberry">raspberry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">mango</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peach" title="Peach">peach</a>. In the early twenty-first century yogurt flavors inspired by desserts, such as chocolate or cheesecake, have been available.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Strained_yogurt">Strained yogurt</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Strained_yogurt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Strained yogurt (page does not exist)">Strained yogurt</a> is yogurt which has been strained through a paper or cloth filter, traditionally made of <a href="/wiki/Muslin" title="Muslin">muslin</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}, to remove the <a href="/wiki/Whey" title="Whey">whey</a>, giving a much thicker consistency and a distinctive, slightly tangy taste. Strained yogurt is becoming more popular with those who make yogurt at home, especially if using skim milk which results in a thinner consistency. Once yogurt is made and refrigerated overnight, it is poured in a muslin or cheesecloth bag and hung in the coolest place in the house, with a tub placed underneath to collect the dripping whey. In cold weather a single day (or night) of straining is sufficient. In higher ambient temperatures yogurt will spoil rapidly, therefore it had best be actively squeezed or strained until about a third or more of its initial weight has run off. The remainder is now strained and is refrigerated again.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Labneh" title="Labneh" class="mw-redirect">Labneh</a> is a strained yogurt used for <a href="/wiki/Sandwich" title="Sandwich">sandwiches</a> popular in Arab countries. Olive oil, cucumber slices, olives, and various green herbs may be added. It can be thickened further and rolled into balls, preserved in olive oil, and fermented for a few more weeks. It is sometimes used with onions, meat, and nuts as a stuffing for a variety of pies or <a href="/wiki/Kebbeh" title="Kebbeh" class="mw-redirect">kebbeh</a> (كبة) balls.
</p><p>Some types of strained yogurts are boiled in open vats first, so that the liquid content is reduced. The popular East Indian dessert, a variation of traditional dahi called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mishti_doi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mishti doi (page does not exist)">mishti dahi</a>, offers a thicker, more custard-like consistency, and is usually sweeter than western yogurts.
</p><p>Strained yogurt is also enjoyed in <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> and is the main component of <i><a href="/wiki/Tzatziki" title="Tzatziki" class="mw-redirect">tzatziki</a></i> (from Turkish "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Cac%C4%B1k&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cacık (page does not exist)">cacık</a>"), a well-known accompaniment to <a href="/wiki/Gyro_(food)" title="Gyro (food)">gyros</a> and <a href="/wiki/Souvlaki" title="Souvlaki">souvlaki</a> pita sandwiches: it is a yogurt sauce or dip made with the addition of grated <a href="/wiki/Cucumber" title="Cucumber">cucumber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salt" title="Salt">salt</a> and, optionally, mashed <a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">garlic</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Srikhand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Srikhand (page does not exist)">Srikhand</a>, a popular dessert in India, is made from strained yogurt, <a href="/wiki/Saffron" title="Saffron">saffron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardamom" title="Cardamom">cardamom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nutmeg" title="Nutmeg">nutmeg</a> and sugar and sometimes fruits such as <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">mango</a> or <a href="/wiki/Pineapple" title="Pineapple">pineapple</a>.
</p><p>In North America, strained yogurt is commonly called "Greek yogurt".
</p><p><br />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Beverages">Beverages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fresh_ayran.jpg" title="File:Fresh ayran.jpg">File:Fresh ayran.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ayran" title="Ayran">Ayran</a>. One of the popular beverages in <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yogurtjf.JPG" title="File:Yogurtjf.JPG">File:Yogurtjf.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">PCC Dairy Yogurt Milk, with live cultures, made from water buffalo's cream milk <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philippine_Carabao_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philippine Carabao Center (page does not exist)">Philippine Carabao Center</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Dugh" title="Dugh" class="mw-redirect">Dugh</a> ("dawghe" in <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Neo-Aramaic" title="Assyrian Neo-Aramaic">Neo-Aramaic</a>), <a href="/wiki/Ayran" title="Ayran">ayran</a> or dhallë is a yogurt-based, salty drink popular in <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_Macedonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of Macedonia (page does not exist)">Republic of Macedonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a>. It is made by mixing yogurt with water and (sometimes) salt. The same drink is known as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Doogh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doogh (page does not exist)">doogh</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>; <i>tan</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Armenia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Armenia (page does not exist)">Armenia</a>; <i>laban ayran</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Syria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Syria (page does not exist)">Syria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>; <i>shenina</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq (page does not exist)">Iraq</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jordan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jordan (page does not exist)">Jordan</a>; <i>laban arbil</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq (page does not exist)">Iraq</a>; <i>majjiga</i> (<a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a>), <i>majjige</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Kannada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kannada (page does not exist)">Kannada</a>), and <i>moru</i> (<a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malayalam" title="Malayalam">Malayalam</a>) in <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South India</a>; namkeen <i><a href="/wiki/Lassi" title="Lassi">lassi</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjab</a> and all over <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>. A similar drink, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doogh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doogh (page does not exist)">doogh</a>, is popular in the Middle East between Lebanon, Iran, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq (page does not exist)">Iraq</a>; it differs from ayran by the addition of herbs, usually <a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">mint</a>, and is sometimes carbonated, commonly with <a href="/wiki/Carbonated_water" title="Carbonated water">carbonated water</a>.
</p><p>Borhani (or Burhani) is a spicy yogurt drink popular in <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> and parts of <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a>. It is usually served with kacchi <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryani</a> at weddings and special feasts. Key ingredients are yogurt blended with mint leaves (<a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">mentha</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mustard_seeds&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mustard seeds (page does not exist)">mustard seeds</a> and black rock salt (<a href="/wiki/Kala_Namak" title="Kala Namak">Kala Namak</a>). Ground roasted <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a>, ground <a href="/wiki/White_pepper" title="White pepper" class="mw-redirect">white pepper</a>, green <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">chili pepper</a> paste and sugar are often added.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lassi" title="Lassi">Lassi</a> (Hindi: लस्सी, Urdu: لسی) is a yogurt-based beverage originally from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian subcontinent</a> that is usually slightly salty or sweet. Lassi is a staple in Punjab. In some parts of the subcontinent, the sweet version may be commercially flavored with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rosewater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rosewater (page does not exist)">rosewater</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">mango</a> or other fruit juice to create a very different drink. Salty lassi is usually flavored with ground, roasted <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">red chilies</a>; this salty variation may also use buttermilk, and in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is interchangeably called <i>ghol</i> (<a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a>), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mattha&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mattha (page does not exist)">mattha</a></i> (North India), "majjige" (<a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>), <i>majjiga</i> (<a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a>), <i>moru</i> (<a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kerala&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kerala (page does not exist)">Kerala</a>), <i>Dahi paani</i> (<a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a>), <i>tak</i> (<a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a>), or <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chaas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chaas (page does not exist)">chaas</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>). Lassi is very widely drunk in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>. Mango Lassi is a popular drink at Indian restaurants in US.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_Macedonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of Macedonia (page does not exist)">Republic of Macedonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>, an unsweetened and unsalted yogurt drink usually called simply <i>jogurt</i> is a popular accompaniment to <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Burek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burek (page does not exist)">burek</a></i> and other <a href="/wiki/Bakery" title="Bakery">bakery</a> products.
</p><p>Sweetened yogurt drinks are the usual form in Europe (including the UK) and the US, containing fruit and added sweeteners. These are typically called "drinking / drinkable yogurt", such as <a href="/wiki/Yop" title="Yop">Yop</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=BioBest_Smoothie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BioBest Smoothie (page does not exist)">BioBest Smoothie</a>.
</p><p>Also available are "yogurt smoothies", which contain a higher proportion of fruit and are more like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smoothie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smoothie (page does not exist)">smoothies</a>. In <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, yogurt smoothies flavored with native fruit are served with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pan_de_yuca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pan de yuca (page does not exist)">pan de yuca</a> as a common type of <a href="/wiki/Fast_food" title="Fast food">fast food</a>.
</p><p>Also in Turkey, yogurt-soup or <i>Yayla Çorbası</i> is a popular way of consuming yogurt. The soup is a mix of yogurt, rice, flour and dried mint.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-dairy_yogurts">Non-dairy yogurts</span></h3>
<p>Since at least 1977 yogurt has been made from soy milk.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} As of Sept. 2012 at least 174 commercial soy yogurts,
both spoonable and drinkable, have been launched worldwide, including 83 in the USA and 58 in Europe<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Making_yogurt_at_home">Making yogurt at home</span></h3>
<p>Yogurt is made by inoculating certain bacteria (starter culture), usually <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Streptococcus_thermophilus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Streptococcus thermophilus (page does not exist)">Streptococcus thermophilus</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactobacillus_bulgaricus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactobacillus bulgaricus (page does not exist)">Lactobacillus bulgaricus</a></i>, into milk. After inoculation, the milk is incubated at approximately 110°F ± 5°F until firm; the milk is coagulated by bacteria-produced lactic acid. 
</p><p>The milk used to make yogurt contains a higher concentration of solids than normal milk. By increasing the solids content of the milk, a firm, rather than soft, end product results. Addition of nonfat dry milk (NFDM) is the easiest at-home method for doing this.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Another method is using scalded milk: heating milk near boiling, then letting it cool down. The process <a href="/wiki/Denaturation_(biochemistry)" title="Denaturation (biochemistry)">denaturates</a> whey proteins, which makes yogurt thicker.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> 
</p><p>The yogurt making process provides two significant barriers to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pathogen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pathogen (page does not exist)">pathogen</a> growth: (a) heat and (b) acidity (low pH). Both are necessary to ensure a safe product. Acidity alone has been questioned by recent outbreaks of food poisoning by <i><a href="/wiki/E._coli_O157:H7" title="E. coli O157:H7" class="mw-redirect">E. coli O157:H7</a></i> that is acid-tolerant. <i>E. coli O157:H7</i> is easily destroyed by pasteurization (heating). Therefore, pasteurized milk is used for making yogurt.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>This initial process is the first step in making <a href="/w/index.php?title=Strained_yogurt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Strained yogurt (page does not exist)">strained yogurt</a> as mentioned above by eliminating some of the liquid whey. Koji (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aspergillus_oryzae&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aspergillus oryzae (page does not exist)">Aspergillus oryzae</a></i>) starter kits and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kefir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kefir (page does not exist)">kefir</a> grains are also used in the home for making a wide variety of fermented dairy, soy and wheat products.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p>

</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<table class="metadata plainlinks mbox-small" style="padding:0.25em 0.5em 0.5em 0.75em;border:1px solid #aaa;background:#f9f9f9;">
